data.text:
Today, I touch upon how the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive ("CS3D") will affect businesses that are not within its "direct" scope. In-scope businesses have a legal obligation under the Directive to adopt and implement effective due diligence policies for identifying, preventing, mitigating, and ending human rights and environmental harms. These requirements extend to: 1. An in-scope company's own activities; 2. The activities of a company it controls (e.g., a subsidiary); 3. The activities of direct and indirect business partners in its ‚Äúchain of activities‚Äù. A ‚Äúchain of activities‚Äù includes activities in an upstream and downstream value chain; a reference to a sometimes lengthy and complex supply chain that exists in any sector or industry. The upstream value chain includes suppliers who specialise in extracting, transporting, and storing raw materials, product design, and manufacturing. For example, if your company extracts, processes, or produces raw materials for a company that is in-scope, then you are part of the upstream ‚Äúchain of activities‚Äù or if you handle the distribution or onward storage of an in-scope company‚Äôs products, or you deal with disposal of its products (including dismantling, recycling, or landfilling) you will be part of downstream ‚Äúchain of activities‚Äù. I like to think of it as the "before" and "after" product/ service process. The CS3D will have a cascading effect on global supply chains because of the wide reach of the term ‚Äúchain of activities‚Äù.
